Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 11:16AM kelty wrote: Best wishes to Hannah!
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 06:09PM kelty wrote: Most people used the phrase "your health problem". I'm Ok with it.  I really didn't feel sick before the chemo started. Cancer is just such a strange thing.
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 02:08PM kelty wrote: Thanks Nikki for your post. Let's stay in touch. I do get a lot of family support. Seeing your picture reminded me that I need to have a good picture taken with me holding my baby Kyle before the surgery.  It's been so overwhleming in the last few months.  I had a C-section so my daughter knows to be gentle with me.  We told her I will have to go to the hospital to have a big "boo-boo" fixed next week.  She seems to be Ok with that so far.  But it's sad to see that she was doing pretend play with her cart and bear friends going to the hospital.  My husband told the daycare teachers my situation last Friday and they will help us to look after her if there's anything weird going on. I'm lucky that I found this place for her with those wonderful teachers she adores.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 01:41PM kelty wrote: Hello, all, I have a question on tests before and after chemo. I've done chest X-ray, blood work(for liver) and will do heart MUGAscan. I wonder if there's any other tests you've done. My oncologist doesn't think CT or PET scan is necessary.  I also asked him what follow up tests will be done to know if the chemo if effective or not and if there's recurrance. He basically told me that regular physical exam is all I need. Unless there're symptoms he won't even ask for additional CT/PET scans. Is that normal? I thought some doctors also check CA markers in blood. My doctor told me that those markers are not reliable for BC patients, they only increase my anxiety level.  I do like my oncologist a lot. He baiscally tells me that I need to try to live a normal life and leave the cancer problem to him.  But I still can't help worry that the cancer will sneak up again in some unexpected place in my body.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 12:30PM - edited Jan 27, 2009 12:33PM by kelty I will have my chemo port inserted either late this week or next. I'm so tired of the surgical room and anesthesia.  It'll be my 4th surgery in the last 4 months (including the C-section).  Why don't they put it in during the mastectomy? I did ask my Onc and radiologist about the diet.  The radiologist said don't eat too much antioxidants during the radiation since it may remove the free radicals generated by the radiation and compomise the effect. Once I'm done with the treatment, everything is OK.  He also asked me to wait for 3-4 months before the breast reconstruction because it takes a while for the scar tissues from the radiation to "settle down"? I think I should not worry about the tests any more and try to live a normal life and leave the treatment to my doctors. My daughter's 3th birthday is coming up. It's much more fun to plan her birthday party than worrying about my treatment.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 12:58PM - edited Feb 1, 2009 12:59PM by kelty Nikki, Welcome back. Did you start to lose hair or you chose to cut it yourself? I will start my Chemo on 02/09. I decided to host my daughter's birthday party on 02/22, the day before my second shot. I wonder if I will still have enough hair by 02/22 or need to wear a wig already.  My chemo is differnt from yours though, DD ACx4+Taxol x12.  I got a package of wig, scarf, and a night hat from local ACS, the night hat and the scarf are nice but I'd like to find a cuter and softer wig and maybe a few more scarf.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: kelty wrote: This is really hard on me. 2.5 half yrs after my mom died of BC and 3 months after my son was born. I also have a daughter who's almost 3 yrs old. I got my report back on Jan 6th with IDC, grade 3.  Since the size of the tumor is quite big, the surgeon has suggested to do masectomy on my right breast. Still waiting for MRI and other test results. Dx 1/6/2009, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 11:18AM kelty wrote: Got my third AC this week.  It was quite bad, but the good news is only one more AC to go. The third day was the worst, I felt really beaten up and stayed in bed most of the time. But I felt much better today and continued my walking routine. I've asked my husband to shave my head a month ago. It actually felt good.  No more bad hair days! I used to have a lot of hair, it takes a long time to dry, now I can show and wipe my head and that's it.  the BC DX is a wake up call for me and also an opportunity to reflect my lifestyle and try to live a better more healthy life afterwards. I've been reading "anticancer - a new way of life", I found it extremely inspiring. I'll definitely try to get more antioxidants in my body after the treatments. I'm still in the process of reading various books to work out my getting well plan.  My baby just had his first pair of teeth coming out. Now his sister can no longer say " he can't eat the food because he doesn't have teeth!"
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 08:03AM kelty wrote: Lisa, Did you save a skin flap for the breast reconstruction? I'm a bit worried about there may be cancer cells there too. But I heard it may be radiated first.  I haven't researched on the reconstruction part yet. I just want to be done with the mastectomy and start with the chemo asap. Nothing is more important than fighting the cancer so I can be there for my kids.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Still waiting for MRI and other test results. Dx 1/6/2009, IDC, 4cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/6 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 01:37PM - edited Feb 2, 2009 01:39PM by kelty My older one asked me today if my boo-boo's getting better now that we can play everything together. She loves being swinged and since my surgery, we told her only once to be gentle with mommy and don't pull my right arm and jump into me like she used to do. She's been doing great and very careful not to hurt my "boo-boo".  We had a good time playing outside in the sandbox today, and she sang the pirate song for me and told me it was "a little off key" just like the real pirates did. It made me laugh so hard.  But apparently she's still thinking about my "boo-boo". I found the older they get and it's more and more difficult to deal with parents' sickness.  My 4 month old is growing quickly every day. He's laughing aloud nowadays.  I love kissing and smelling him and making him laugh.  He enjoys "the wheels on the bus" song alot. It always brings smile to him. The other funny thing about him, he's so used to look at the bears on the crib bumper and when I left him in the "sleep and play" downstairs this morning for a little tummy time, he had this confused look on his face and turned his head all directions like saying "where's my bears friends"?
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 11:47AM kelty wrote: Lisa,  I did have MUGA scan, haven't heard anything from my oncologist's office after the test, assuming it's OK. I didn't know what MUGA scan was before went there. When the tech explained to me how it works, I told him that he's the first one in my life who took my blood and gave it back to me! Also got my Emend pills for the first round. Hope it works!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 11:32AM - edited Feb 7, 2009 11:35AM by kelty Lisa, this is GREAT your scans are clear!  Sounds like you are ready to MOVE ON! I got my port inserted yesterday morning, it's still really sore today. There's this big bump right under my collarbone probably because I'm quite skinny. It feels so weird. Tomorrow's supposed to be a nice day.  I plan to go wig shopping with a friend.  There's a local shop owned and staffed by cancer survivors.  They take insurance too, how nice.  Hopefully I can take my kids out for a walk on Sunday. I think there's some type of steroid given during chemo, the nurse warmed me of being restless but I can't remember with which drug and when. I'm still debating what to bring for lunch during the chemo. Did you have any apetite to eat anything during chemo? What do you do to kill time during chemo? I've got some books and bookstore gift cards from my coworkers and friends.  I wonder if I should bring some books with me. The muga scan is a bit strange that they took a small amount of my blood and mixed in radioactive material and injected it back to me then I was scanned by a machine for 30 mins like you did. I guess the procedure of injection can vary slightly depending on where it was done.  I was able to go back to work for two days this week and it felt so good (sort of having my normal life back).
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 11:56AM - edited Feb 13, 2009 11:59AM by kelty Lisa, thanks for your detailed reply.  I found some reviews on PSK(extract of Coriolus versicolor) very interesting.  Also my dietrician has recommended me to take some vitamin D. Will talk to my Onc to see what he thinks especially during chemo treatment.  It looks like my daughter may have got stomach flu from her daycare, last thing I want to see during chemo.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2009 04:21AM kelty wrote: I went to see my Onc on Tuesday, he was on vacation this Monday.  He's not happy about the number either. He said he doesn't want to see this again and will have to cut the chemo dose next time. I'm really petite and skinny and with chronic blood disorder problem (I've been seeing a hematologist for several years, he thinks it's an autoimmune problem), so my reserve of white blood cell and platelet has always been borderline low (or below border line in the case of platelet). He explained to me the difference of Neupogen and Neulasta.  He said Neulasta will be active in my body for two weeks and he wants to wait for a few days to see if my counts come back by Friday since the blood count typically bottoms out around 8th day.  He also put me on preventative antibotics now and asked me to wear mask when my daughter comes home from daycare.  This is the part that really sucks! I can't be hugging and kissing her this week and most likely I won't be able to attend her birthday party this Sunday.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 04:34PM kelty wrote: Lisa, I'm shocked to hear this!  I thought everything's been going well. Please be strong and take good care of yourself!  I will pray for you!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 08:59AM kelty wrote: Thank you all for the encouragement and inspiration! I went to a workshop today organized by the local breast cancer association for newly diagnosed patients.  The nurse and the social worker there were amazing.  Will see my oncologist for the first time tomorrow.  I will also go to see a genetic consultant tomorrow for genetic testing.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 01:49AM kelty wrote: Thanks Lisa and dlb823.  My surgeron told me no shower only sponge bath till the drain tube is out.  But it looks like he should be able to remove the tube tomorrow.  My local BC support group gave newly diagnosed patients a package of a homemade comfort quilt, a beautiful pouch with ribbon to hang around the neck for the drain tube, and a pillow to put underneath the seat belt.  I'm just so touched to see how much people want to help.  The teachers of my daughter's daycare told us that they can prepare lunch for my daughter and even cook meals for the entire family if needed.  Since I have a lot of family help now, cooking is not a problem, but I heard they are doing this for another family who's also dealing with cancer.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 12:21PM kelty wrote: Lisa,  My tumor was removed on 12/23. The surgeon decided to do a surgerical removal of the whole tumor instead of a biopsy because it was weird looking and raised above the skin. When they found out it is cancer, he suggested mastectomy since the tumor is big compared to my breast size. That's what I had on 01/16.  Everything came out of the mastectomy is clean, nodes and all the breast and skin tissues. My oncologist said there is still 20% chance of microscopic cancer in my blood, so they will go ahead with chemo and rad. So my chemo is after the surgery and it starts on 02/09/2009.  But because I don't have any detectable cancer in my body now, I wonder how they would know if chemo is effective or not.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 10:45AM kelty wrote: Lisa, I'm glad you are starting to plan on your new life and work towards solving the problems.  It's not easy given all these things you have to deal with. But you are such a strong girl, you can definitely work it out! My white blood cell did come back by Friday as my ONC predicted. I was able to go to my daughter's birthday (we held it at the little gym)!  Everybody had a great time! That huge smile on my daughter's face just melt my heart away.  Even my 4 month old baby had a blast, he was jumping on the side laughing along with the older kids. My onc decided today to delay my treatment till next week because my platelet is still not up yet. Hopefully by next Monday it's high enough to start the treatment.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: May 10, 2009 07:39PM - edited May 10, 2009 07:42PM by kelty Hi, WorriedMom98, I first found a lump 6 weeks before the due date.  My OB said it may be a cyst since it was very smooth, and I had the ultrasound done. It was 1.8cm, not a cyst, but there's a bruise mark on it (I have low platelet problem, I get bruises easily). the doctor who reviewed ultrasound thought it may be a hematoma. THe OB decided to wait after the delivery.  SHe was pregnant at the time too, when I went back for the 4 weeks check up, she was on her maternity leave and the nurse who works with her did the exam, she didn't look at the lump at all, just told me to do another ultrasound to see if it's changing size.  I was nursing at the time. the second ultrasound was reviewed by another doctor, he told me it can't be hematoma, go ahead to order a surgical bisopy immediately.  I had the lump removed on Dec 23rd, the surgeon told me he was not sure what it is by looking at the lump.  But ti was big: 4.7 cm. Because of the holiday, didn't get the report back till Jan 6th.  I thought no news was good news, but the surgeon came in my exam room and told me that unfortunately it was cancer. I didn't feel much pain with the lump. it was close to the skin and sort of popped out eventually with blood vessels around it. It's glad you are planning to have the biopsy done. THe wait is the worst.  If you can, try not to think about that and enjoy the time with your baby.  Thinking about it won't change anything and it will make you feel much worse. I really hope you DO NOT have cancer. But remember it is not the end of the world even if it is cancer.  The cancer journey has changed my life greatly, but surprisingly a lot of the changes are very positive.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 07:38AM kelty wrote: I'm back from the mastectomy surgery. Everything went well.  The sentinel nodes were negative.  The surgery seems to be easier on me than the previous C-sections. The drain tube is a bit annoying especially I can't take shower with it.  Will meet with the doctors for chemo and radiation plan this Friday.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 01:16PM kelty wrote: Lisa, I'm sorry your husband isn't giving you enough emotional support at this difficult time.  My dad was sort of like that while my mom was dealing with her BC. I love my dad , but he's just not the kind who can emotionally support others. All he can talk about is work. The way he deals with problems is to work more. Now I'm going through this and I wish I could have given my mom more support. I'm lucky my husband is very caring. But sometimes people who don't have cancer just don't understand. I'm learning to tell him exaxctly what I need from him and we try to spend some time discuss things every night after kids go to bed. Raising kids can be overwhelming too. Besides I'd rather exhaust myself with the kids sometimes so I don't have to think or talk about cancer. I'm sure our hubbies can be the same.  I can't imagine dealing with this and raising a child all by yourself. You have to worry about job security too- as a single mom you can't afford to lose health insurance. I really hope you can work it out with your husband! And always remember to take good care of yourself first.  I read somewhere BC patients are often women who like to take care of others. I found it's true with a lot of people I know. It's time to treat ourselves well.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 01:19PM - edited Feb 2, 2009 01:20PM by kelty Lisa,  You are amazingly strong. Reading your post is always inspiring for me.  I'm sure you can work anything out.  Will have the chemo talk tomorrow and my port inserted this Thursday. The chemo time is getting closer every day. My anxiety level is definitely going up - last two blood pressure measurements was 110-115/83-85.  I'm always 110/65-75 even during the pregnancies!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 11:35AM - edited Feb 4, 2009 11:48AM by kelty Hi, bemurray, the waiting part is the worst, once you have a treatment plan, you will feel much better.  "I also have a 4 yr old and will do anything to stay alive to be with her - its funny how un-important everything else has become. " This is so true. My mom in law told me after my brother -in law was born, she got really sick and the doctors told her that there's nothing they can do to help. She was lying in the bed in the hospital and fell asleep. In her dream she went to this place it's so peaceful. All her pains went away. She would like to stay there forever, but then she thought about her kids and woke up instantly. After that she got better every day. Now she's almost 70 and very healthy.  We have to keep faith that we can beat this for our little ones. When my husband and I told our friends and coworkers about the DX, I was amazed to hear so many women we know are BC survivors, I would have never guessed.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 08:57AM kelty wrote: Lisa, Thanks. It turned out my daughter just caught cold air and she was doing well the next day.  I felt a bit down today. I got the new pathlogy report from NCI (I requested for second opinion). The tissues from the second surgery( themastetomy) did show DCIS involving lobules and residual infiltrating carcinoma. THis is different from what my surgeon told me after the mastectomy that everything was clear. But the up side is that it was the right decision for me to have the mastectomy right away. I started another thread on PSK, you can check it out:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/79/topic/728849?page=1#idx_17

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 10:22AM kelty wrote: DAy 7 after my first AC, did blood work today and the nurse told me that there's barely any white blood cell to be found. I need to be extremely careful to prevent infection.  Sounds really scary, anyone heard of similar situation?  I took a Neulasta shot 1 day after the chemo. The hemoglobin is about 10 AND the platelet is around 44, also quite low. I don't feel that though, that's really strange.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 01:59AM kelty wrote: Hello, Lisa, Thanks for sharing your story. You are just amazing and so brave!  I was confirmed to be triple negative yesterday.  Still debating whether to do double mastectomy or not.  The MRI came back to be OK with the other breast. I have the genetic testing done yesterday, will do the right breast mastectomy tomorrow and also find out how many lump nodes are affected.  My oncologist recommended Adriamycin + cytoxan every 2 weeks for 4 times and then taxol every week for 12 times. Also he asked me to consider the Avastin clinical trial. If anybody has any comments on that treatment, I will really appreciate that.  There's nothing that gives me more courage to face this than my little ones. Looking at them playing is the best way to relieve my stress. Hugs!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 12:06PM kelty wrote: First chemo today. Not too bad so far. The session itself was just 1 hr, the waiting doctor's exam took 2 hrs. The muscle feels funny now. I will try to get a good night sleep tonight since I had no nap today. I think the Emend must have helped. I was nervous while waiting in the Onc's office. He gave the "go" and asked me to take Emend. And half an hour later I felt much more relax for no reason.  Anyone has similar experience? Lisa, did you mention you take quite a bit of antioxidants? I talked to my Onc today about taking grape seed extracts.  He said he's not strongly against it, but he personally doesn't support it either.  He said there's a study done looking at the effect of taking antioxidants and various vitamins during or after chemo. They didn't find any benefit for taking such supplements , in fact for certain supplements, they have a small negative effect. He thinks the best way to get antioxidants and vitamins is through food. Somehow it is much better absorbed when in the food form.  Have you talked to your doctor on this? I wonder what other doctors say about supplements.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 12:39AM kelty wrote: Lisa, Sorry to hear that your baby was sick and your lymphdema problem.  Kids are so easy to get sick in the spring. I remember the first year my daughter was in daycare.  She was sick ALL the time. But once their immune system is built up, it'll be much better. I guess it's the same for us with BC. We really need to take good care of ourselves and try to rebuild our immune system to fight with cancer. I read that the first 4 years after pregnancy, the risk for BC is high. There's no clear explanantion, but it can be the body has suppressed the immune system to support the pregancy.  I heard people can be caught of lymphdema years after the surgery. And flying can increase the risk.  I've been seeing a therapist for a few times to get baseline measurement and tips for recovery after mastectomy. She suggests me to get the compression garment if I need to get on an airplane. I've been doing fairly well, my white count was up to 7.4 this time, YEAH! But the platelet is still a bit low. Keep my finger crossed that my daughter won't get nasty bugs from her daycare!  My inlaws are staying with us during my treatment to help us with the baby and the housework. They are just wonderful.  I finally started to learn to let go a little and take good care of myself first. Hope everything gets better with you! You are such a strong woman!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 3 months after giving birth to my second child kelty kelty

With a toddler and a newborn, it's hard to avoid some degree of activities with the right arm. But my in-laws are very helpful and they are carrying the baby for me now.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 10:30AM kelty wrote: Hi, Silverlining, my situation is very similar to your. I was also diagnosed with IDC on 01/06 whiling still nursing. I will go through a mastectomy on 01/16. Now I'm really nervous while wiating for the surgery.  The worst part is not sure about myself any more.  Anything even occasional cough makes me wonder if there's something bad going on. I feel my lymph nodes under both armpits are swelling, but not sure if it's due to the sudden stop of milk production or anything else.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed w/aggressive IDC theredheadamy kim40

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 09:01AM kelty wrote: I'm also debating if I should have a bilateral mast. I just went through the mastectomy on 01/16.  The recovery was fairly easy. But given my family history and the aggresvieness of my cancer, I'm leaning towards bilateral now. When I was diagnosed on 01/06, I decided to go ahead with the sugery and treatment (chemo/rad) as soon as possible and leave the bilateral decision for a later time at the reconstruction surgery. Right now I just have too many things to deal with. I don't know if I can make a rational decision on this. I'm 35 yrs with a toddler girl and a new born boy( 4 months). Movinon, It looks like your tunor was caught on at a much earlier stage than mine. You should have a really good chance for a cancer free recovery.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, Mastectomy or Bi-Lateral Mastectomy movinOn movinOn
